  • JavaScript

Functions

Declaring a function

We can use functions to section off small bits of logic or tasks that we can then call when we need. Functions can help take large problems and break them into small manageable chunks that can be reused.

To create a function it must first be declared using the function keyword. Declaring the function gives the function a name. The name should describe what the function is to do when it is called.

                        

// Example function declaration
function functionName () {

}

Calling a function

Defining a function does not execute it. The function needs to be called for it to be used.

                        

// Call the function
functionName ();

Lets now create a function that computes the area of a circle.

                        

/*
@param {number} The radius of the circle
@return {number} The area of the circle
*/
function circleArea ( radius ) {

    return radius * radius * Math.PI;

}

circleArea (3);

Return statement

The return statement specifies the value to be returned by the function and tells the browser to return the result so it can be made available and used outside of the function. This is necessary as any variable declared inside the function is only available within that function. This is called variable scoping.

                        

return value;

Reusing functions

Functions can be made to be reusable. This code example turns the computer on if it's off, and off if the computer is on. This block of code within the function is executed twice.

                        

var computerOn = false;

function pressPowerButton () {

    // computerOn boolean value is 'true'
    if ( computerOn ) {
        console.log( 'Computer turning off.' );
        computerOn = false;
    // computerOn boolean value is 'false'
    } else {
        console.log( 'Computer turning on.' );
        computerOn = true;
    }

}

pressPowerButton ();   // Computer turning on
pressPowerButton ();   // Computer turning off

We can use functions to section off small bits of logic:

                        

var orderCount = 0;

// Function to take the pizza orders
function takeOrder ( crustType, topping ) {

    // Increment each time an order is placed
    orderCount = orderCount + 1;
    // Output each order to the console
    console.log( 'Order: ' + crustType + ' crust & ' + topping + ' topping.' );

}

// Function to calculate subtotal of the order
function getSubTotal ( orderCount ) {

    // Return number of orders multiplied by the cost per pizza
    return ( orderCount * 7.50 );

}

// Function to calculate VAT at 20%
function getTax () {

    // Return 20% of the subtotal
    return getSubTotal ( orderCount ) / 100 * 20;

}

// Function to calculate total cost of the order
function getTotal () {

    // Return the subtotal and add VAT
    return getSubTotal ( orderCount ) + getTax ();

}

// Create the order
takeOrder ( 'thin', 'pineapple' );
takeOrder ( 'thick', 'mushroom' );
takeOrder ( 'thick', 'cheese' );

// Number of items in the order
console.log( 'Items: ' + orderCount );
// Subtotal to two decimal places
console.log( 'Subtotal: £' + getSubTotal ( orderCount ).toFixed(2) );
// Total to two decimal places
console.log( 'Total (including VAT @ 20%): £' + getTotal ().toFixed(2) );

Parameters and Arguments

To pass values into a function we can use paremeters and arguments. The values are passed into the function as arguments into the parameters within the parenthesis of the function declaration.

In the following example, a simple function takes two numbers as arguments and passes them into the num1 and num2 parameters. These values are then multiplied together and returned using the return statement.

When we call the function, the two values we want to multiply are passed as arguments into the function.

                        

// Declare a function with two parameters
function multiplyNumbers ( num1, num2 ) {

   // Return the total of num1 * num2
   return num1 * num2;

}

// Call the function and pass two arguments
multiplyNumbers ( 4, 2 );

When dealing with functions that accept a large number of optional arguments, instead of passing the large number of arguments in conventional fashion, you can pass just one argument which ends up being a collection of arguments declared in an object literal.

The function only requires a small number of arguments (args), which is a collection of all the values passed from the object literal. This is ideal for a collection of arguments that may grow over time rather than a small number of arguments.

More information about the object literal can be found here.

                        

function player ( args ) {

    console.log( 'Name: ' + args.name );
    console.log( 'Team: ' + args.team );

}

// Call the function and pass in the object literal
player ( {
    name : 'Lionel Messi',
    team : 'Barcelona FC'
} );

Returning more than one value

We can also use functions to return more than one value at a time using an array.

This next example calculates both the area and volume. The values are stored in two variables, before being added to an array called sizes which returns the results.

                        

function calculateSize ( width, height, depth ) {

   var area = width * height;
   var volume = width * height * depth;
   // Array to contain the area and volume values
   var sizes = [ area, volume ];
   // Return the sizes array
   return sizes;

}

// Array index is [0] so the area will be calculated
var getArea = calculateSize ( 3, 2, 5 )[0];
// Array index is [1] so the volume will be calculated
var getVolume = calculateSize ( 3, 2, 5 )[1];

getArea;
getVolume;
